title: Are GMOs good or bad?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between selective breeding and genetic engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: Genetic engineering is slower than selective breeding.

options.label: B
options.text: Genetic engineering is faster than selective breeding.

options.label: C
options.text: Genetic engineering allows for the choice of specific traits, while selective breeding relies on luck.

options.label: D
options.text: Genetic engineering is only used for plants, while selective breeding is used for animals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concern about GM crops mixing with traditional crops and introducing unwanted new characteristics?

options.label: A
options.text: Gene flow

options.label: B
options.text: Terminator seeds

options.label: C
options.text: Pesticide resistance

options.label: D
options.text: Climate change

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of BT crops, which produce a protein that destroys the digestive system of specific insect pests?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce a pesticide that can be sprayed on crops

options.label: B
options.text: To make crops resistant to certain weed killers

options.label: C
options.text: To produce a protein that is harmless to humans but toxic to insects

options.label: D
options.text: To make crops more attractive to beneficial insects

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the fundamental problems with the GMO debate?

options.label: A
options.text: The lack of scientific evidence supporting the use of GMOs

options.label: B
options.text: The over-reliance on a single method of weed control

options.label: C
options.text: The potential for GMOs to spread to non-GMO crops

options.label: D
options.text: The high cost of developing and using GMOs

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential benefit of GMOs in agriculture?

options.label: A
options.text: They can increase the use of pesticides and herbicides

options.label: B
options.text: They can help to reduce the environmental impact of agriculture

options.label: C
options.text: They can only be used for large-scale industrial farming

options.label: D
options.text: They can only be used for organic farming

title: How the world's first metro system was built - Christian Wolmar

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial reaction of the public towards the idea of building a subway system in London?

options.label: A
options.text: They were enthusiastic and supportive.

options.label: B
options.text: They were skeptical and thought it would never work.

options.label: C
options.text: They were neutral and didn't have an opinion.

options.label: D
options.text: They were opposed to it due to environmental concerns.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: "Tunnel and fill"

options.label: C
options.text: "Bore and build"

options.label: D
options.text: "Dig and cover"

options.label: B
options.text: The City and South London

options.label: C
options.text: The London Underground

options.label: D
options.text: The Tube

options.label: B
options.text: The Tunnel Borer

options.label: C
options.text: The Subterranean Drill

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: The Cambodian myth of lightning, thunder, and rain - Prumsodun Ok

multiple-choice.question: What was the contest announced by Lok Ta for his three students?

options.label: A
options.text: Whoever could collect the most leaves in the forest.

options.label: B
options.text: Whoever could bring back a glass full of morning dew.

options.label: C
options.text: Whoever could climb the highest mountain.

options.label: D
options.text: Whoever could swim the farthest in the sea.

multiple-choice.question: How did Moni Mekhala win the contest?

options.label: A
options.text: By collecting the morning dew directly from a flower.

options.label: B
options.text: By wringing out her shawl over a glass.

options.label: C
options.text: By singing a song to the morning dew.

options.label: D
options.text: By using magic to make the morning dew appear.

multiple-choice.question: What gift did Lok Ta give to Moni Mekhala?

options.label: A
options.text: A diamond axe.

options.label: B
options.text: A magic dagger.

options.label: C
options.text: A crystal ball unlike anything ever seen.

options.label: D
options.text: A golden crown.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Ream Eyso try to take the crystal ball from Moni Mekhala by force?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he wanted to use it to help his friends.

options.label: B
options.text: Because he wanted to show off his strength.

options.label: C
options.text: Because he was jealous of Mekhala's prize.

options.label: D
options.text: Because he was ordered to by Lok Ta.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Ream Eyso after Moni Mekhala threw her crystal into the air?

options.label: A
options.text: He was able to see again and continued his pursuit of Mekhala.

options.label: B
options.text: He was blinded by the powerful flashes of lightning and became impotent without his axe.

options.label: C
options.text: He was able to fly faster and caught up to Mekhala.

options.label: D
options.text: He was turned into a stone statue.

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: He was honored through statues and temples.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The size of teeth.

options.label: B
options.text: To shearing meat and sinew.

options.label: C
options.text: To crush hard roots and seeds.

options.label: D

options.text: He must not ride on his horse

options.label: B
options.text: He must not touch the earth with his own feet

options.label: C
options.text: He must not forget his friends and family

options.label: D
options.text: He must not use his superhuman strength

title: The tragic myth of Orpheus and Eurydice - Brendan Pelsue

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the musician who journeyed to the land of the dead to rescue his beloved wife, Eurydice?

options.label: A
options.text: Orpheus

options.label: B
options.text: Eurydice

options.label: C
options.text: Hades

options.label: D
options.text: Cerberus

multiple-choice.question: What was the condition set by Hades and Persephone for Orpheus to be reunited with Eurydice?

options.label: A
options.text: That Orpheus must sing a song of love to Hades and Persephone

options.label: B
options.text: That Orpheus must not turn around to see if Eurydice was following behind him

options.label: C
options.text: That Orpheus must bring a gift to the underworld

options.label: D
options.text: That Orpheus must stay in the underworld forever

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Orpheus when he gave in to temptation and looked back at Eurydice?

options.label: A
options.text: He was reunited with Eurydice

options.label: B
options.text: He was granted a wish by Hades

options.label: C
options.text: He was refused entry back into the underworld

options.label: D
options.text: He was transformed into a snake

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Orpheus's love and loss?

options.label: A
options.text: He became a bitter person

options.label: B
options.text: He lost his talent for music

options.label: C
options.text: He gained a new perspective on love and created a new art form, the love poem

options.label: D
options.text: He became a recluse

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Orpheus after his death?

options.label: A
options.text: He was reborn as a bird

options.label: B
options.text: He was transformed into a tree

options.label: C
options.text: He found peace and walked with Eurydice along the banks of the River Styx

options.label: D
options.text: He was reincarnated as a human

title: How does the immune system work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the immune system?

options.label: A
options.text: To fight off threats to our bodies by destroying foreign cells and substances.

options.label: B
options.text: To produce special proteins called antibodies to fight off invaders.

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate body temperature and maintain overall health.

options.label: D
options.text: To clear bodily toxins and waste from the body.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two main cellular groups that coordinate a two-pronged attack in the immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: Phagocytes and lymphocytes

options.label: B
options.text: Macrophages and dendritic cells

options.label: C
options.text: T-cells and B-cells

options.label: D
options.text: Helper T-cells and phagocytes

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of antibodies in the immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: To destroy foreign cells and substances.

options.label: B
options.text: To identify antigens and transmit information to lymphocytes.

options.label: C
options.text: To latch onto invaders like a lock and key and destroy them.

options.label: D
options.text: To aid in the reproduction of bacteria and viruses.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of the immune system in terms of long-term immunity?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps us develop immunity to certain diseases, like chickenpox.

options.label: B
options.text: B: It helps us fight off colds and other potential infections.

options.label: C
options.text: It regulates body temperature and maintains overall health.

options.label: D
options.text: It clears bodily toxins and waste from the body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the immune system's response to a threat and its purpose?

options.label: A
options.text: The immune system's response is immediate, while its purpose is to prevent the threat from escalating.

options.label: B
options.text: The immune system's response is to destroy foreign cells and substances, while its purpose is to fight off threats to our bodies.

options.label: C
options.text: The immune system's response is to produce special proteins called antibodies, while its purpose is to regulate body temperature and maintain overall health.

options.label: D
options.text: The immune system's response is to clear bodily toxins and waste from the body, while its purpose is to fight off threats to our bodies.

title: Why should you read Charles Dickens? - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What is a notable feature of Charles Dickens's writing that made it so special?

options.label: A
options.text: His use of poetic language

options.label: B
options.text: His ability to create complex characters

options.label: C
options.text: His ability to create anticipation through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries

options.label: D
options.text: His use of satire in his stories

options.label: A
options.text: They were released as a single book

options.label: B
options.text: They were serialized in literary journals

options.label: C
options.text: They were released in chapters, with cliffhangers and revelations

options.label: D
options.text: They were only available to a select audience

multiple-choice.question: What was a significant influence on Dickens's depiction of society in his novels?

options.label: A
options.text: His experiences as a wealthy businessman

options.label: B
options.text: His experiences as a child working in a boot blacking factory

options.label: C
options.text: His travels to other countries

options.label: D
options.text: His education at a prestigious university

multiple-choice.question: What is a common theme in many of Dickens's novels, including Nicholas Nickleby and Oliver Twist?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of wealth and status

options.label: B
options.text: The struggles of the working class

options.label: C
options.text: The power of love and relationships

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of technology on society

multiple-choice.question: What is notable about Dickens's London in his novels?

options.label: A
options.text: It is depicted as a utopian society

options.label: B
options.text: It is depicted as a harsh and corrupt world

options.label: C
options.text: It is depicted as a neutral and unchanging city

options.label: D
options.text: It is depicted as a place of pure wonder and possibility

title: How do fish make electricity? - Eleanor Nelsen

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why fish use electrical signals underwater?

options.label: A
options.text: To communicate with other fish

options.label: B
options.text: To navigate through the water

options.label: C
options.text: To find and hunt prey

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

options.label: A
options.text: Electric eel

options.label: B
options.text: Electric catfish

options.label: C
options.text: Weakly electric fish

options.label: D
options.text: Strongly electric fish

options.label: A
options.text: Electric organ

options.label: B
options.text: Electroreceptor

options.label: C
options.text: Electrocyte

options.label: D
options.text: Schnauzenorgan

options.label: A
options.text: Weakly electric fish are larger than strongly electric fish

options.label: B
options.text: Weakly electric fish produce more electricity than strongly electric fish

options.label: C
options.text: Weakly electric fish produce enough electricity to attack their prey

options.label: D
options.text: Weakly electric fish produce less electricity than strongly electric fish

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Electric ray

options.label: D

title: The Bystander Effect: The science of empathy

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what happens when people are in a group and someone needs help?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more likely to help each other.

options.label: B
options.text: They feel a sense of responsibility and help the person in need.

options.label: C
options.text: They tend to feel that someone else will take care of it and do nothing.

options.label: D
options.text: They start arguing with each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon where people in a group are less likely to help someone in need called?

options.label: A
options.text: The diffusion of responsibility

options.label: B
options.text: The bystander effect

options.label: C
options.text: The helplessness effect

options.label: D
options.text: The social influence effect

multiple-choice.question: What is the average time it took for participants in a group of 10 people to offer help to someone in need?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 minute and 30 seconds

options.label: B
options.text: 3 minutes and 19 seconds

options.label: C
options.text: 7 minutes and 25 seconds

options.label: D
options.text: 8 minutes and 1 second

multiple-choice.question: Why are people in a group less likely to help someone in need?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are shy and don't want to be seen as helping.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they think someone else will take care of it.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are not feeling well.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not interested in helping.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of being alone when someone needs help?

options.label: A
options.text: You are more likely to be distracted and not help.

options.label: B
options.text: You are more likely to feel a sense of responsibility and help the person in need.

options.label: C
options.text: You are more likely to feel shy and not help.

options.label: D
options.text: You are more likely to think someone else will take care of it.

multiple-choice.question: Where did surfing originate?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: It was a sport with spiritual and social significance

options.label: C
options.text: It was a way to show off one's wealth and status

options.label: D

options.text: Only shortboards

options.label: C
options.text: Alaia boards, paipo boards, and olo boards

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Duke Kahanamoku

options.label: C
options.text: Alexander Hume Ford

options.label: D
options.text: William Anderson, a surgeon on Captain Cook's ship "Resolution"

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the American colonizers exploiting surfing'surfing's native-led revival?

options.label: A
options.text: Surfing became a popular sport only among Hawaiians

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: The myth of Prometheus - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: According to Greek mythology, what was the task entrusted to Prometheus and his brother Epimetheus by Zeus after the battle against the Titans?

options.label: A
options.text: To destroy the remaining Titans.

options.label: B
options.text: To create the gods and goddesses.

options.label: C
options.text: To create all living things.

options.label: D
options.text: To punish the gods for their victory.

multiple-choice.question: What was the gift that Prometheus gave to humans when he shaped them out of mud?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to fly.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to move through water.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to think and reason.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to live forever.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Zeus punish Prometheus by chaining him to a cliff for eternity?

options.label: A
options.text: Because Prometheus refused to worship him.

options.label: B
options.text: Because Prometheus stole fire from the gods.

options.label: C
options.text: Because Prometheus deceived Zeus by hiding the best portion of the bull under the belly.

options.label: D
options.text: Because Prometheus's actions gave humans an advantage over the gods.

multiple-choice.question: In Percy Bysshe Shelley's lyrical drama "Prometheus Unbound," what is Prometheus portrayed as?

options.label: A
options.text: A cautionary figure.

options.label: B
options.text: A trickster.

options.label: C
options.text: A romantic hero.

options.label: D
options.text: A villain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of Prometheus in mythology and literature?

options.label: A
options.text: He is a symbol of human weakness and vulnerability.

options.label: B
options.text: He is a symbol of the power of the gods over humans.

options.label: C
options.text: He is a symbol of our capacity to capture the powers of nature.

options.label: D
options.text: He is a symbol of the dangers of science and technology.

options.label: B
options.text: The Scottish Play

options.label: C
options.text: Macbeth

options.label: C
options.text: The History of Scotland

multiple-choice.question: What is the phrase that Macbeth and his wife Lady Macbeth use to justify their actions in the play?

options.label: B
options.text: "What's done is done"

options.label: C
options.text: "Fair is foul and foul is fair"

options.label: D

options.text: "Double, double toil and trouble; Fire burn, and caldron bubble"

options.label: B
options.text: "What's done is done"

options.label: C
options.text: "The milk of human kindness"

options.label: D
options.text: "Out, out, brief candle!"

options.label: B

options.text: "Fair is foul and foul is fair"

options.label: D

title: Where do math symbols come from? - John David Walters

multiple-choice.question: What motivated Robert Recorde to invent the equals sign?

options.label: A
options.text: He wanted to create a new way to represent the concept of infinity.

options.label: B
options.text: He was tired of writing the words "is equal to" over and over.

options.label: C
options.text: He wanted to create a symbol that would represent the number zero.

options.label: D
options.text: He was inspired by the Latin word "et" meaning and.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Robert Recorde choose to use two parallel horizontal line segments for the equals sign?

options.label: A
options.text: He thought it would be more visually appealing than other options.

options.label: B
options.text: He believed that no two things can be more equal.

options.label: C
options.text: He wanted to create a symbol that would be easily recognizable.

options.label: D
options.text: He was trying to create a symbol that would represent the concept of equality.

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the plus sign (+) for addition?

options.label: A
options.text: It was invented by Robert Recorde as a symbol for infinity.

options.label: B
options.text: It originated from the Latin word "et" meaning and.

options.label: C
options.text: It was introduced by Christian Kramp as a shorthand for factorials.

options.label: D
options.text: It was created by a mathematician who wanted to avoid repeating himself.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the exponent in a mathematical expression?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to represent a number that is being squared.

options.label: B
options.text: It indicates how many times a number should be repeated in a multiplication operation.

options.label: C
options.text: It is used to represent a number that is being added to itself.

options.label: D
options.text: It is used to represent a number that is being subtracted from itself.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the symbol σ (sigma) in mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to represent the number pi (π).

options.label: B
options.text: It is used to represent the concept of infinity.

options.label: C
options.text: It is used to indicate the repeated addition of a number.

options.label: D
options.text: It is used to represent the concept of equality.

multiple-choice.question: B: He was tired of writing the words "is equal to" over and over.
B: He believed that no two things can be more equal.
B: It originated from the Latin word "et" meaning and.
B: It indicates how many times a number should be repeated in a multiplication operation.
C: It is used to indicate the repeated addition of a number.
